elements.content: Photoluminescent isotypical phosphonate-based metal–organic frameworks, [Ln­(H5btp)]·2H2O [where Ln3+ = Tb3+ (1) or Gd3+ (2) and H8btp = [1,1′-biphenyl]-3,3′,5,5′-tetrayltetrakis­(phosphonic acid)] prepared under solvo­(hydro)­thermal conditions exhibit a three-dimensional supramolecular structure built up from phosphonate linkers bridging Ln3+ ions. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction of 1 revealed hydrogen bonds along the a-axis between the crystallization water molecules and the phosphonate groups. The network features lozenge-shaped tubular channels with intermolecular interactions between adjacent organic ligand molecules. Crystal packing forces bring together two ligand biphenyl groups in a parallel arrangement, forming an excimer. A ratiometric luminescent thermometer operative close to room temperature was built based on the excimer and the 5D4 → 7F5 Tb3+ emissions, exhibiting a maximum relative thermal sensitivity of 1.26%·K–1 and a minimum temperature uncertainty of 0.75 K at 319 K. This performance is similar to that of a thermometer based on the ligand singlet S 2,1 → S 0 and metal 5D4 → 7F5 transitions. Thus, the same MOF material provides two separate temperature data sets. This work shows the possibility of using excimer emissions in ratiometric luminescence thermometry.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction of 1 revealed hydrogen bonds along the a-axis between the crystallization water molecules and the phosphonate groups. The network features lozenge-shaped tubular channels with intermolecular interactions between adjacent organic ligand molecules. Crystal packing forces bring together two ligand biphenyl groups in a parallel arrangement, forming an excimer. A ratiometric luminescent thermometer operative close to room temperature was built based on the excimer and the 5D4 → 7F5 Tb3+ emissions, exhibiting a maximum relative thermal sensitivity of 1.26%⋅K-1 and a minimum temperature uncertainty of 0.75 K at 319 K. This performance is similar to that of a thermometer based on the ligand singlet S 2,1 → S 0 and metal 5D4 → 7F5 transitions. Thus, the same MOF material provides two separate temperature data sets. elements.content: Frameworks of crystalline organic–inorganic hybrid materials, so-called metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) and coordination polymers, are built by linking metal ions via strong covalent interactions. The very wide choice of metal ions and ligands enables the design and synthesis of materials with desired functionality and porosity.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Frameworks of crystalline organic-inorganic hybrid materials, so-called metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and coordination polymers, are built by linking metal ions via strong covalent interactions. The very wide choice of metal ions and ligands enables the design and synthesis of materials with desired functionality and porosity.

elements.content: Lanthanide-bearing MOFs have been much explored as luminescent materials for applications in, for example, imaging, light-emitting diodes, chemical sensors, and luminescent ratiometric thermometry. Ln-bearing MOF ratiometric thermometers work in an accurate, essentially noninvasive way and are based on the dual emission from two luminescent centers: two different Ln3+ ions (in general, Eu3+/Tb3+) or one Ln3+ ion and an organic species (linker or guest residing in the micropores).
elements.clean_text: Lanthanide-bearing MOFs have been much explored as luminescent materials for applications in, for example, imaging, light-emitting diodes, chemical sensors, and luminescent ratiometric thermometry. Ln-bearing MOF ratiometric thermometers work in an accurate, essentially noninvasive way and are based on the dual emission from two luminescent centers: two different Ln3+ ions (in general, Eu3+/Tb3+) or one Ln3+ ion and an organic species (linker or guest residing in the micropores).

elements.content: We have recently described a number of MOFs based on the tetraphosphonate ligand [1,1′-biphenyl]-3,3′,5,5′-tetrayltetrakis­(phosphonic acid) (H8btp) (Figure S1) and Y3+ and La3+ cations, some of which were doped with Eu3+ and Tb3+, and their luminescence properties were studied. Here, we report isotypical Tb3+ (1) and Gd3+ (2) materials, formulated as [Ln­(H5btp)]·2H2O, prepared under hydro­(solvo)­thermal conditions. Compound 1 is a novel type of ratiometric luminescent thermometer based on the emissions of both Tb3+ and an excimer (i.e., a dimer in an excited state), operative, in particular, in the physiological temperature range. This excimer arises from the association (in a parallel arrangement) of two ligand biphenyl groups brought together by crystal packing. To the best of our knowledge, 1 is the first example of an optical thermometer relying on dual Ln-excimer emission and also one of the very few Ln-bearing MOFs exhibiting excimer fluorescence. Occurrence of excimers in MOFs is not uncommon: π–π interactions between the aromatic linkers favor excimer emission in, among others, materials containing pyrene, naphthalene, anthracene, phenanthroline, and 1,2-bis­[4-pyridyl]­ethane.

Here, we report isotypical Tb3+ (1) and Gd3+ (2) materials, formulated as [Ln(H5btp)]⋅2H2O, prepared under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions. Compound 1 is a novel type of ratiometric luminescent thermometer based on the emissions of both Tb3+ and an excimer (i.e., a dimer in an excited state), operative, in particular, in the physiological temperature range. This excimer arises from the association (in a parallel arrangement) of two ligand biphenyl groups brought together by crystal packing. elements.content: [1,1′-Biphenyl]-3,3′,5,5′-tetrayltetrakis­(phosphonic acid) (H8btp) was prepared via the optimized procedure previously reported by us. All other chemicals, including solvents, were readily available from commercial sources and were used as received without further purification: lanthanide­(III) chloride hexahydrates (LnCl3·6H2O, Ln3+ = Gd3+ and Tb3+, 99.9%, Sigma–Aldrich), hydrochloric acid (37%, José Manuel Gomes dos Santos Lta.), methanol (>99.8%, Fluka), and potassium bromide (for infrared spectroscopy, >99%, BDH SpectrosoL).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

[1,1'-Biphenyl]-3,3',5,5'-tetrayltetrakis(phosphonic acid) (H8btp) was prepared via the optimized procedure previously reported by us. All other chemicals, including solvents, were readily available from commercial sources and were used as received without further purification: lanthanide(III) chloride hexahydrates (LnCl3⋅6H2O, Ln3+ = Gd3+ and Tb3+, 99.9%, Sigma-Aldrich), hydrochloric acid (37%, José Manuel Gomes dos Santos Lta.), methanol (>99.8%, Fluka), and potassium bromide (for infrared spectroscopy, >99%, BDH SpectrosoL).

elements.content: SEM (scanning electron microscopic) images were acquired on either a Hitachi S4100 field-emission gun tungsten filament instrument working at 25 kV or a high-resolution Hitachi SU-70 working at 4 kV. Samples were prepared by deposition on aluminum sample holders, followed by carbon coating with an Emitech K950X carbon evaporator.

elements.content: Routine powder X-ray diffraction data for the materials were collected at ambient temperature on a Empyrean PANalytical diffractometer (Cu Kα1,2 X-radiation, λ1 = 1.540 598 Å, λ2 = 1.544 426 Å), equipped with an PIXcel 1D detector and a flat-plate sample holder in a Bragg–Brentano para-focusing optics configuration (45 kV, 40 mA). Intensity data were collected by the step-counting method (step 0.01°), in continuous mode, in the ca. 3.5° ≤ 2θ ≤ 50° range.

elements.content: Emission and excitation spectra were recorded with a Fluorolog3 Horiba Scientific (model FL3-2T) spectroscope, with a modular double-grating excitation spectrometer (fitted with a 1200 grooves/mm grating blazed at 330 nm) and a Triax 320 single-emission monochromator (fitted with a 1200 grooves/mm grating blazed at 500 nm, reciprocal linear density of 2.6 nm·mm–1), coupled to a R928 Hamamatsu photomultiplier, using the front-face acquisition mode. The excitation source was a 450 W Xe arc lamp. Emission spectra were corrected for detection and optical spectral response of the spectrofluorimeter, and excitation spectra were corrected for the spectral distribution of lamp intensity by use of a photodiode reference detector. Time-resolved emission measurements were carried out on a 1934D3 phosphorimeter coupled to the Fluorolog3, and a Xe–Hg flash lamp (6 μs/pulse half width and 20–30 μs tail) was used as the excitation source. Measurements at 13 K were performed on a helium-closed cycle cryostat with vacuum system measuring ca. 5 × 10–6 mbar. The nanosecond emission decay curves were acquired with a similar spectrofluorometer (Fluorolog3 Horiba Scientific; model FL3-22) coupled to a FL1073 Horiba photomultiplier (950 V) with a pulsed NanoLED-330 (Horiba Scientific) as the excitation source. Instrumental function response for the NanoLED-330 was obtained by use of a Ludox (colloidal silica) scattering water solution.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence

Emission and excitation spectra were recorded with a Fluorolog3 Horiba Scientific (model FL3-2T) spectroscope, with a modular double-grating excitation spectrometer (fitted with a 1200 grooves/mm grating blazed at 330 nm) and a Triax 320 single-emission monochromator (fitted with a 1200 grooves/mm grating blazed at 500 nm, reciprocal linear density of 2.6 nm⋅mm-1), coupled to a R928 Hamamatsu photomultiplier, using the front-face acquisition mode. The excitation source was a 450 W Xe arc lamp. Emission spectra were corrected for detection and optical spectral response of the spectrofluorimeter, and excitation spectra were corrected for the spectral distribution of lamp intensity by use of a photodiode reference detector. Time-resolved emission measurements were carried out on a 1934D3 phosphorimeter coupled to the Fluorolog3, and a Xe-Hg flash lamp (6 μs/pulse half width and 20-30 μs tail) was used as the excitation source. Measurements at 13 K were performed on a helium-closed cycle cryostat with vacuum system measuring ca. 5 × 10-6 mbar. The nanosecond emission decay curves were acquired with a similar spectrofluorometer (Fluorolog3 Horiba Scientific; model FL3-22) coupled to a FL1073 Horiba photomultiplier (950 V) with a pulsed NanoLED-330 (Horiba Scientific) as the excitation source. Instrumental function response for the NanoLED-330 was obtained by use of a Ludox (colloidal silica) scattering water solution.

elements.content: Temperature-dependent measurements were performed by use of a Kapton thermofoil heater (Minco) mounted on a Cu holder and coupled to a temperature controller (IES-RD31). The temperature controller incorporates a Barnant thermocouple 100 (model 600-2820) with a temperature accuracy of 0.1 K, according to the manufacturer. The four consecutive emission spectra (3 min/scan) for each temperature were recorded after waiting at least 10 min to thermalize the sample; the maximum temperature difference detected during the acquisitions was 0.2 K, twice the temperature controller accuracy.

elements.content: Reactive mixtures composed of the respective lanthanide­(III) chloride hydrates [LnCl3·6H2O, where Ln3+ = Tb3+ (1) and Gd3+ (2)] and 0.025 g of [1,1′-biphenyl]-3,3′,5,5′-tetrayltetrakis­(phosphonic acid) (H8btp), with an overall molar ratio of approximately 1:4 (H8btp:Ln3+), were prepared in a mixture of distilled water, HCl (6 M), and methanol (2 mL each) at ambient temperature. Mixtures were kept under constant magnetic stirring in open air for approximately 15 min. The resulting homogeneous suspensions were transferred to Teflon-lined Parr Instrument reaction vessels and placed inside an MMM Venticell oven. The heating program included (i) heating for 48 h up to 140 °C, (ii) 24 h maintenance of the temperature (140 °C), and (iii) cooling for 48 h until ambient temperature was reached. The resulting materials were isolated as white microcrystalline powders, recovered by vacuum filtration, washed with abundant amounts of distilled water, and dried at ambient temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Ln(H5btp)]⋅2H2O

Reactive mixtures composed of the respective lanthanide(III) chloride hydrates [LnCl3⋅6H2O, where Ln3+ = Tb3+ (1) and Gd3+ (2)] and 0.025 g of [1,1'-biphenyl]-3,3',5,5'-tetrayltetrakis(phosphonic acid) (H8btp), with an overall molar ratio of approximately 1:4 (H8btp:Ln3+), were prepared in a mixture of distilled water, HCl (6 M), and methanol (2 mL each) at ambient temperature. Mixtures were kept under constant magnetic stirring in open air for approximately 15 min. The resulting homogeneous suspensions were transferred to Teflon-lined Parr Instrument reaction vessels and placed inside an MMM Venticell oven. The heating program included (i) heating for 48 h up to 140 °C, (ii) 24 h maintenance of the temperature (140 °C), and (iii) cooling for 48 h until ambient temperature was reached. The resulting materials were isolated as white microcrystalline powders, recovered by vacuum filtration, washed with abundant amounts of distilled water, and dried at ambient temperature.

elements.content: Inspection of various batches of the products isolated from hydro­(solvo)­thermal syntheses was performed by use of a Stemi 2000 stereomicroscope equipped with Carl Zeiss lenses. This allowed the identification of abundant long white needles (dimensions of about 0.06 × 0.02 × 0.01 mm), which were studied by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Needles were manually selected and harvested from the batch solution and immersed in highly viscous Fomblin Y perfluoropolyether vacuum oil (LVAC 140/13, Sigma–Aldrich) to avoid degradation caused by evaporation of the solvent. Crystals were mounted on Hampton Research cryoloops, and preliminary X-ray diffraction data were collected at 180(2) K on a Bruker D8 Quest equipped with Mo Kα sealed tube (λ = 0.710 73 Å), a multilayer Triumph X-ray mirror, a Photon 100 complementary metal oxide semiconductor (CMOS) detector, and an Oxford Instruments Cryostrem 700+ series low-temperature device. The instrument was controlled with the APEX2 software package.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction Studies

Inspection of various batches of the products isolated from hydro(solvo)thermal syntheses was performed by use of a Stemi 2000 stereomicroscope equipped with Carl Zeiss lenses. This allowed the identification of abundant long white needles (dimensions of about 0.06 × 0.02 × 0.01 mm), which were studied by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Needles were manually selected and harvested from the batch solution and immersed in highly viscous Fomblin Y perfluoropolyether vacuum oil (LVAC 140/13, Sigma-Aldrich) to avoid degradation caused by evaporation of the solvent. Crystals were mounted on Hampton Research cryoloops, and preliminary X-ray diffraction data were collected at 180(2) K on a Bruker D8 Quest equipped with Mo Kα sealed tube (λ = 0.71073 Å), a multilayer Triumph X-ray mirror, a Photon 100 complementary metal oxide semiconductor (CMOS) detector, and an Oxford Instruments Cryostrem 700+ series low-temperature device. The instrument was controlled with the APEX2 software package.

elements.content: Diffraction images were processed by the software package SAINT+, and data were corrected for absorption by the multiscan semiempirical method implemented in SADABS. The crystal structure of [Tb­(H5btp)]·2H2O (1) was solved by use of the algorithm implemented in SHELXT-2014, which allowed the immediate location of almost all of the heaviest atoms composing the asymmetric unit of the material. The remaining missing and misplaced non-hydrogen atoms were located from difference Fourier maps calculated from successive full-matrix least-squares refinement cycles on F 2 by use of the latest SHELXL from the 2014 release. All structural refinements were performed with the graphical interface ShelXle.

The remaining missing and misplaced non-hydrogen atoms were located from difference Fourier maps calculated from successive full-matrix least-squares refinement cycles on F 2 by use of the latest SHELXL from the 2014 release. All structural refinements were performed with the graphical interface ShelXle.

elements.content: Hydrogen atoms bound to carbon were placed at their idealized positions by use of HFIX 43 in SHELXL-2014, and these were included in subsequent refinement cycles with isotropic displacement parameters (U iso) fixed at 1.2 times U eq of the parent carbon atoms. Hydrogen atoms associated with water molecules could not be located from difference Fourier maps, and no attempts were made to place them in calculated positions. These atoms were, however, included in the empirical formula of the compound (Table S5). Hydrogen atoms associated with the terminal -POH groups were located from difference Fourier maps and placed by taking into account the environment of the terminal oxygen atom and the P–O distances. Note that, to confirm which groups should be protonated, it was necessary to simultaneously take into account the P–O bond lengths and the possibility of forming hydrogen bonds with neighboring moieties. These atoms were placed and refined with the assumption of isotropic thermal displacement parameters (U iso) fixed at 1.5 times U eq of the parent oxygen atoms and with the O–H distances restrained to 0.95(1) Å. In order to maintain the neutrality of the compound, one of these hydrogen atoms (H5) is disordered and was refined with an occupation rate of 50%.

elements.content: The last difference Fourier map synthesis showed the highest peak (1.500 e·Å–3) and the deepest hole (−0.749 e·Å–3), located at 1.01 and 0.80 Å from Tb1. Structural refinements were performed with the graphical interface ShelXle. Structural drawings have been created by use of the software package Crystal Impact Diamond. Information concerning crystallographic data collection and structure refinement details is summarized in Table S5. Tables S1 and S2 gather the most significant geometrical parameters of the crystallographically independent Tb3+ coordination sphere and possible supramolecular contacts.

elements.content: Geometry optimizations, in the gas phase and without symmetry constraints, for the ground-state singlet (S 0) and low-lying singlet excited states (S 1 and S2) of H8btp ligand were performed by density functional theory (DFT) and time-dependent density functional theory (TD-DFT) methods, respectively. The lowest triplet state was investigated with the spin-unrestricted method. Calculated expectation values for the total spin operator, ⟨S 2⟩, prior to spin annihilation are 2.0605 for the triplet-state structure and become 2.0022 after annihilation of the first spin contamination, sufficiently close to the expected ⟨S 2⟩ = 2 for triplet states. For all calculations we employed the PBE0 functional with the D95­(d,p) basis set. Harmonic vibrational frequencies were calculated at the same level for all optimized structures, which were shown to have no negative eigenvalues for the Hessian matrices. By use of the S 0 structure, vertical electronic excitation energies related to absorption in solution were obtained by TD-DFT calculations at the same level as the geometry optimization and included the solvent effects via the polarizable continuum model (PCM). Oscillator strengths were deduced from the dipole transition matrix elements, and the solvent used in the PCM calculations was ethanol. United atom topological model radii were employed to generate the solute cavity within the PCM implementation. The fluorescence electronic transitions were calculated as vertical de-excitations based on the TD-DFT-optimized geometry of the S 1 and S2 states. Adiabatic transition wavenumber for the triplet state of H8btp ligand was calculated within the framework of the so-called ΔSCF procedure. All quantum chemistry calculations were performed with Gaussian 09W, revision A.02, using its default criteria.
elements.clean_text:
Calculation Details

Geometry optimizations, in the gas phase and without symmetry constraints, for the ground-state singlet (S 0) and low-lying singlet excited states (S 1 and S2) of H8btp ligand were performed by density functional theory (DFT) and time-dependent density functional theory (TD-DFT) methods, respectively. The lowest triplet state was investigated with the spin-unrestricted method. Calculated expectation values for the total spin operator, ⟨S 2⟩, prior to spin annihilation are 2.0605 for the triplet-state structure and become 2.0022 after annihilation of the first spin contamination, sufficiently close to the expected ⟨S 2⟩ = 2 for triplet states. For all calculations we employed the PBE0 functional with the D95(d,p) basis set. Harmonic vibrational frequencies were calculated at the same level for all optimized structures, which were shown to have no negative eigenvalues for the Hessian matrices. By use of the S 0 structure, vertical electronic excitation energies related to absorption in solution were obtained by TD-DFT calculations at the same level as the geometry optimization and included the solvent effects via the polarizable continuum model (PCM). Oscillator strengths were deduced from the dipole transition matrix elements, and the solvent used in the PCM calculations was ethanol. United atom topological model radii were employed to generate the solute cavity within the PCM implementation. The fluorescence electronic transitions were calculated as vertical de-excitations based on the TD-DFT-optimized geometry of the S 1 and S2 states. Adiabatic transition wavenumber for the triplet state of H8btp ligand was calculated within the framework of the so-called ΔSCF procedure. All quantum chemistry calculations were performed with Gaussian 09W, revision A.02, using its default criteria.

elements.content: Following our previous work on H8btp-based MOFs, we used 5-day hydro­(solvo)­thermal synthesis to investigate the effect of the heating process on the obtained networks. Because H8btp has proved to be a suitable organic linker to sensitize Tb3+ cations when present as dopant, it was of interest to assess the properties of a stoichiometric Tb3+-only framework. The isolated [Ln­(H5btp)]·2H2O [Ln3+ = Tb3+ (1) or Gd3+ (2)] feature essentially the same structural and topological features of Y3+-MOFs ([Y­(H5btp)]·5.5H2O, [Y­(H5btp)]·2.5H2O, and (H3O)­[Y2(H5btp)­(H4btp)]·H2O). Materials were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction, to assess the phase purity and homogeneity of the bulk materials (Figure S2), and one was further studied by single-crystal X-ray diffraction.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Crystal Morphology

Following our previous work on H8btp-based MOFs, we used 5-day hydro(solvo)thermal synthesis to investigate the effect of the heating process on the obtained networks. Because H8btp has proved to be a suitable organic linker to sensitize Tb3+ cations when present as dopant, it was of interest to assess the properties of a stoichiometric Tb3+-only framework. The isolated [Ln(H5btp)]⋅2H2O [Ln3+ = Tb3+ (1) or Gd3+ (2)] feature essentially the same structural and topological features of Y3+-MOFs ([Y(H5btp)]⋅5.5H2O, [Y(H5btp)]⋅2.5H2O, and (H3O)[Y2(H5btp)(H4btp)]⋅H2O). Materials were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction, to assess the phase purity and homogeneity of the bulk materials (Figure S2), and one was further studied by single-crystal X-ray diffraction.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of half a metal center, half a H5btp3– ligand, and one disordered water molecule of crystallization. Tb3+ is coordinated to six phosphonate moieties from six individual H5btp3– anionic ligands, forming a slightly distorted {TbO6} octahedron (). This coordination geometry is uncommon among LnOFs whose metal coordination numbers usually range between 7 and 9 (as witnessed by the Cambridge Structural Database, CSD). Only a few examples of phosphonate-based MOFs with this type of lanthanide coordination are known. Among MOFs bearing [1,1′-biphenyl]-3,3′,5,5′-tetracarboxylic acid (a ligand with the same skeleton of H8btp but with carboxylic acid groups as coordinating moieties), there are no CSD reports of this kind of Ln coordination. Low lanthanide coordination numbers often preclude the presence of coordinated solvent molecules, such as water, which usually degrade the luminescence properties by providing nonradiative pathways.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of half a metal center, half a H5btp3- ligand, and one disordered water molecule of crystallization. Tb3+ is coordinated to six phosphonate moieties from six individual H5btp3- anionic ligands, forming a slightly distorted {TbO6} octahedron (). This coordination geometry is uncommon among LnOFs whose metal coordination numbers usually range between 7 and 9 (as witnessed by the Cambridge Structural Database, CSD). Only a few examples of phosphonate-based MOFs with this type of lanthanide coordination are known. Among MOFs bearing [1,1'-biphenyl]-3,3',5,5'-tetracarboxylic acid (a ligand with the same skeleton of H8btp but with carboxylic acid groups as coordinating moieties), there are no CSD reports of this kind of Ln coordination. Low lanthanide coordination numbers often preclude the presence of coordinated solvent molecules, such as water, which usually degrade the luminescence properties by providing nonradiative pathways.

elements.content: (a) Crystal packing of [Tb­(H5btp)]·2H2O (1) along the [001] direction. (Inset) π–π interaction between the aromatic rings along [001] and [010] with a distance of 3.856(6) Å between centroids. (b) Distorted Tb3+ octahedral coordination environment. Symmetry transformations used to generate equivalent atoms: (i) −x + 1, −y + 1, −z + 2; (ii) x, −y + 1, z – 1/2; (iii) −x + 1, y, −z + 3/2; (iv) x, y, z – 1; (v) −x + 1, y, −z + 5/2. Dashed blue lines represent the π–π supramolecular interactions.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Crystal packing of [Tb(H5btp)]⋅2H2O (1) along the [001] direction. (Inset) π-π interaction between the aromatic rings along [001] and [010] with a distance of 3.856(6) Å between centroids. (b) Distorted Tb3+ octahedral coordination environment. Symmetry transformations used to generate equivalent atoms: (i) -x + 1, -y + 1, -z + 2; (ii) x, -y + 1, z - 1/2; (iii) -x + 1, y, -z + 3/2; (iv) x, y, z - 1; (v) -x + 1, y, -z + 5/2. Dashed blue lines represent the π-π supramolecular interactions.

elements.content: Tb–O distances of the distorted {TbO6} octahedron range from 2.225(4) to 2.233(4) Å, while the internal O–Tb–O cis and trans octahedral angles are in the ranges 83.87(19)–102.79(18)° and 163.3(2)–172.7(2)°, respectively (see Table S1 for individual geometrical parameters). Though the bond length dispersion is small (Δ = 0.008 Å), the bulk of the distortion arises from internal octahedral angles, with a dispersion of ca. 18.9° for the cis angles (only 9.5° for the trans angles).

elements.content: H5btp3– acts as a hexadentate linker, connecting six symmetry-equivalent metal centers with the same κ1-O coordination mode. Allied with its inherent rigidity, this leads to the formation of a 3D framework with lozenge tubular channels running along the [001] direction of the unit cell. Parallel to these channels, the framework is composed of zigzag inorganic chains formed by Tb3+ polyhedra interconnected by four phosphonate groups from two different H5btp3– residues, with 5.154(2) Å Tb···Tb distance along the chain. The organic linker bridges these inorganic chains, forming a layer in the bc plane with a longer Tb···Tb distance of 13.054(5) Å. Noncoordinated oxygens are protonated and hydrogen-bonded to crystallization water molecules (Table S2). Additional weak π–π interactions [distance between centroids 3.856(6) Å] ensure a close compact network (, inset).

The organic linker bridges these inorganic chains, forming a layer in the bc plane with a longer Tb⋅⋅⋅Tb distance of 13.054(5) Å. Additional weak π-π interactions [distance between centroids 3.856(6) Å] ensure a close compact network (, inset).

elements.content: [Tb­(H5btp)]·2H2O (1) shares certain structural features with other MOF materials reported previously. All compounds comprise {MO6} octahedra, the most distorted of which is found in 1 (a comparison of distortion indexes is given in Table S3). Three-dimensional networks are arranged by the metal centers in a zigzag conformation connected by the organic linker, with small pores filled with crystallization water molecules. All materials are binodal networks, with a 6,6-connectivity mode and a point symbol of {413.62}­{48.66.8}. The major difference between 1 and the previously reported Y-based networks is the rotation of the organic linker phenyl rings: while the torsion angle between rings is ca. 7.1° in [Y­(H5btp)]·5.5H2O, 12.7° in [Y­(H5btp)]·2.5H2O, and 7.9° in (H3O)­[Y2(H5btp)­(H4btp)]·H2O, there is no significant torsion in 1. This explains why weak π–π interactions are present in 1 and absent in the other MOFs.

This explains why weak π-π interactions are present in 1 and absent in the other MOFs.

elements.content: The UV–vis absorption spectra of H8btp in ethanol solutions (1.0 × 10–4 and 6.2 × 10–4 mol·L–1) exhibit a broad band at 255 nm with high molar absorption coefficients, characteristic of singlet intraligand (1IL) π → π* transitions, and a residual component peaking at ca. 325 nm for the concentrated solution (Figure S3). To rationalize the UV–vis absorption results, the theoretical singlet electronic transitions, oscillator strengths, and molecular orbitals involved in the selected transitions (containing the ethanol solvent effects) were assessed by TD-DFT calculations, for a ground-state H8btp singlet S 0 monomeric structure (Figure S4a). Very good agreement is observed between the calculated lowest singlet, with the largest oscillator strength at 254 nm, and the experimental lowest-energy absorption maximum at 255 nm. A monomeric model cannot explain the small band at 325 nm given by the concentrated solution. This band is ascribed to the equilibrium between monomeric and dimeric structures; that is, to an excimer. To validate this hypothesis, the excitation spectra of H8btp ethanol solutions of concentration 4.0 × 10–5, 2.0 × 10–4, and 1.0 × 10–3 mol·L–1, monitoring the emission at 405 nm, were recorded (Figure S5). As the H8btp concentration decreases, the intensity of the 310–390 nm bands also decreases, in contrast with the increasing intensity of the 260–290 nm bands, confirming the above hypothesis.

Photoluminescence and Time-Dependent Density Functional Theory Calculations

The UV-vis absorption spectra of H8btp in ethanol solutions (1.0 × 10-4 and 6.2 × 10-4 mol⋅L-1) exhibit a broad band at 255 nm with high molar absorption coefficients, characteristic of singlet intraligand (1IL) π → π* transitions, and a residual component peaking at ca. 325 nm for the concentrated solution (Figure S3). To rationalize the UV-vis absorption results, the theoretical singlet electronic transitions, oscillator strengths, and molecular orbitals involved in the selected transitions (containing the ethanol solvent effects) were assessed by TD-DFT calculations, for a ground-state H8btp singlet S 0 monomeric structure (Figure S4a). Very good agreement is observed between the calculated lowest singlet, with the largest oscillator strength at 254 nm, and the experimental lowest-energy absorption maximum at 255 nm. A monomeric model cannot explain the small band at 325 nm given by the concentrated solution. This band is ascribed to the equilibrium between monomeric and dimeric structures; that is, to an excimer. To validate this hypothesis, the excitation spectra of H8btp ethanol solutions of concentration 4.0 × 10-5, 2.0 × 10-4, and 1.0 × 10-3 mol⋅L-1, monitoring the emission at 405 nm, were recorded (Figure S5). As the H8btp concentration decreases, the intensity of the 310-390 nm bands also decreases, in contrast with the increasing intensity of the 260-290 nm bands, confirming the above hypothesis.

elements.content: In order to ascertain the energy levels of the ligand embedded in the MOF, framework 2 was studied (Gd3+ has energy levels only in the high-UV region, <315 nm, allowing ligand emission in the visible spectral range). Consider . The ambient temperature emission spectrum of 2 excited at 300 nm (b) displays two broad bands in the UV (325–388 nm) and violet-blue (400–475 nm) spectral regions. Selective excitation spectra assist the assignment of these ligand transitions (a). The spectrum monitored at 360 nm exhibits a broad UV band from 250 to 325 nm, attributed to the S 0 → S 2,1 H5btp3– ligand transitions. This assignment is in accord with both the absorption spectra of H8btp in ethanolic solution and the TD-DFT calculations. The spectrum monitored at 430 nm displays the S 0 → S 2,1 ligand transitions and a band with three components in the 330–410 nm range ascribed to the excimer (a).

elements.content: Emission spectra of 2 also witness the S 2,1 → S 0 ligand transitions and excimer emission (b). At 12 K, the spectrum excited at 300 nm is dominated by a broad band from ca. 440 to 580 nm, attributed to the ligand’s phosphorescence, with a T 1 triplet-state energy of 22 676 cm–1 (441 nm). However, this phosphorescence disappears upon excitation of the excimer at 370 nm (b). As shown in Figure S6, all the main luminescence characteristics of 2, namely, the fluorescence emission from both S 2,1 and excimer, are observed in the isolated H8btp ligand and, therefore, are intrinsic to it. The low intensity of excimer emission relatively to S 2,1 → S 0 emission (284 nm excitation) is expected, because in the MOF structure π–π interactions between the aromatic rings of the ligands () favor excimer formation. The small shift to higher energy of the emission bands of H8btp in ethanolic solution relative to 2, and the distinct vibronic structure observed for the phosphorescence emission (Figure S6), may be due to the different protonation level and coordination modes of H5btp3–.

elements.content: Ambient temperature emission spectrum of 1 excited at 300 nm (b) shows a series of sharp lines in the 480–690 nm range, assigned to the Tb3 5D4 → 7F6–1 transitions. The two faint broad bands in the 325–375 and 390–475 nm ranges correspond to S 2,1 → S 0 transitions and excimer, respectively. The excitation spectrum (a) recorded by monitoring the Tb3+ green emission at 550 nm is dominated by a broad UV band from ca. 250 to 325 nm, in agreement with the S 0 → S 2,1 ligand transitions observed for 2. The Tb3+ intra-4f8 transitions, such as 7F6 → 5D4,3, are weaker (observed only upon magnification), indicating that the main excitation path is via the ligand energy levels. Both the excimer excitation and emission bands are observed (). At 12 K (Figure S7), there is a strong decrease of the ligand and excimer emissions relative to the Tb3+ emission, indicating an efficient ligand-to-Tb3+ energy transfer.

elements.content: The ambient temperature time-resolved emission spectra of 1 (Figure S8) and the decay curves (Figure S9) further confirm the assignment of S 2,1 → S 0 transition and excimer emission. Indeed, these emissions display similar time dependence, much faster than the intra-4f Tb3+ lines. Moreover, the measured lifetimes (emission at 425 nm) are τ1 = 2.33 ± 0.10 ns, α1 = 94.4%, τ2 = 4.67 ± 0.11 ns, α2 = 5.6%, and χ2 = 2.2 for 1 and τ1 = 2.98 ± 0.05 ns, α1 = 91.0%, τ2 = 5.59 ± 0.14 ns, α2 = 9.0%, and χ2 = 2.4 for 2. The detection of two lifetimes is ascribed to the two distinct H5btp3– coordinating groups revealed by crystallography. Our excitation source does not allow excitation of the S 2,1 emission, and thus the decay curves were not measured. The 5D4 decay curves of 1 were recorded at 295 and 12 K. The data are well-described by single-exponential decay functions (Figure S10), yielding lifetimes of 1.23 ± 0.01 ms at 295 K and 2.92 ± 0.01 ms at 13 K, in agreement with the presence of a single Tb3+ crystallographic site. The increase of emission lifetime with decreasing temperature is the result of nonradiative deactivation pathways, also responsible for the increase in ligand-to-Tb3+ energy transfer.

elements.content: To better understand the nature of the observed emission features, geometry optimization of the low-lying singlet excited states S 1 and S 2 and lowest-lying triplet excited state T 1 of the monomeric H8btp structure was performed at the PBE0/D95­(d,p) level (Figure S4). This molecule assumes a planar configuration in the low-lying excited S 1 and S 2 states and a nonplanar structure in the S 0 ground state. S 1 and S 2 structures are very similar and their energy difference is very small.

This molecule assumes a planar configuration in the low-lying excited S 1 and S 2 states and a nonplanar structure in the S 0 ground state. S 1 and S 2 structures are very similar and their energy difference is very small.

elements.content: From the calculated TD-B3LYP de-excitations (Table S4), the oscillator strength (f = 0.0023) of the lowest-state S 1 at 300 nm is negligible in comparison with the oscillator strength of the second lowest-state S 2 at 288 nm (f = 0.6658). Thus, we tentatively assign the 0–0 onset energy of the singlet fluorescence emission, at ca. 315 nm (black line in Figure S6), to the S 2 emission. The calculated S 1 fluorescence at 300 nm involves the H – 1 → L and H – 1 → L + 1 transitions [where H = highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and L = lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO)], assigned to excitations involving predominantly the biphenyl group but with some contribution from the phosphonate group. In contrast, the contribution of the phosphonate to the S 2 fluorescence at 288 nm, involving the H → L + 1 transition, is almost negligible, in agreement with the 302 nm fluorescence emission of biphenyl in cyclohexane.

elements.content: To the best of our knowledge, an excimer emission has not yet been used for implementing ratiometric luminescence thermometry. Thus, the excimer emission (together with Tb3+ emission) observed in the present system offers a unique opportunity to assess this possibility and to compare it with the more “conventional” optical thermometry based on ligand fluorescence. For this purpose, the ratios of the integrated areas of the 5D4 → 7F5 (I Tb, 534–560 nm) and of the (i) excimer emission (I E , 390–476 nm) and (ii) ligand S 2,1 → S 0 emission (I S, 316–386 nm) were used to define the thermometric parameters (ΔE = I Tb/I E and ΔS = I Tb/I S), allowing the conversion of emission intensities into absolute temperatures. The emission spectra of 1 at 299–319 K are presented in a. Four consecutive emission spectra were recorded at each temperature and used to determine the average thermometric parameters, with the errors calculated from the corresponding standard deviations (95% confidence). From 299 to 319 K, I Tb, I E, and I S decrease 34%, 18%, and 13%, respectively, (b).
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Temperature Dependence

To the best of our knowledge, an excimer emission has not yet been used for implementing ratiometric luminescence thermometry. Thus, the excimer emission (together with Tb3+ emission) observed in the present system offers a unique opportunity to assess this possibility and to compare it with the more "conventional" optical thermometry based on ligand fluorescence. For this purpose, the ratios of the integrated areas of the 5D4 → 7F5 (I Tb, 534-560 nm) and of the (i) excimer emission (I  E , 390-476 nm) and (ii) ligand S 2,1 → S 0 emission (I S, 316-386 nm) were used to define the thermometric parameters (ΔE = I Tb/I E and ΔS = I Tb/I S), allowing the conversion of emission intensities into absolute temperatures. The emission spectra of 1 at 299-319 K are presented in a. Four consecutive emission spectra were recorded at each temperature and used to determine the average thermometric parameters, with the errors calculated from the corresponding standard deviations (95% confidence). From 299 to 319 K, I Tb, I E, and I S decrease 34%, 18%, and 13%, respectively, (b).

elements.content: a depicts the temperature dependence of ΔE and ΔS in the 299–319 K range: solid lines depict the calibration curves obtained by fitting the experimental data with linear equations [Δ­(T) = Δ0 + mT], with Δ0 = 34.94 ± 0.71 and m = 0.0922 ± 0.0023 (r 2 = 0.99) for ΔS and Δ0 = 20.18 ± 0.70 and m = 0.0507 ± 0.0023 (r 2 = 0.98) for ΔE. The corresponding relative sensitivity, defined as S r = |∂Δ/∂T|/Δ, a figure of merit used to compare the performance of thermometers independently of their nature, is shown in b. These ratiometric thermometers exhibit good relative sensitivities in the physiological range, with similar maximal relative sensitivities (S m) of 1.66 and 1.26%·K–1 at 319 K, respectively, for ΔS and ΔE. Thus, even if the singlet-based thermometer outperforms the excimer-based thermometer, the latter is a possible alternative. Concerning S m, the singlet-based thermometer is the third highest reported to date for MOF-based visible luminescent ratiometric thermometers operating in the physiological range. S m of 4.47%·K–1 at 333 K was reported for Tb0.995Eu0.005@In­(OH)­(bpydc), where bpydc = 2,2′-bipyridine-5,5′-dicarboxylic acid, and 2.19%·K–1 at 293 K for Eu@UiO­(bpydc). In addition, at the reference human body temperature (309 K), S r for our ΔS (1.43%·K–1) is similar to the best S r values (1.57 and 1.63%·K–1) reported for prior visible luminescent ratiometric Ln-based MOFs ().

Determined from the calibration function provided by the authors.

The calibration function considers the temperature in degrees Celsius.

The temperature function given by the authors was corrected for T = −57.53 + 78.01Δ instead of T = 57.53 – 78.01Δ.

The temperature uncertainty, δT = 1/S r (δΔ/Δ), is the smallest temperature change that may be ascertained in a given measurement, where δΔ/Δ is the relative error in determination of the thermometric parameter and depends on the acquisition setup. In the 299–319 K range, the minimum temperature uncertainty for ΔS and ΔE is, respectively, 0.44 and 0.75 K obtained at 319 K (Figure S11). Temperature cycling between 299 and 313 K (Figure S12) demonstrates repeatability better than 99% for the ΔS parameter.

elements.content: A final remark on use of the excimer emission in ratiometric luminescent thermometry pertains to emission stability of 1 under UV irradiation. The emission spectra measured upon 300 nm irradiation for periods up to 60 min (Figure S13) show negligible changes in the Tb3+ and S 2,1 → S 0 emissions but a 15% and 22% decrease of the excimer emission after, respectively, 30 and 60 min. This degradation time scale is, however, not a real issue because a single temperature measurement can be accomplished in a few milliseconds by use of a charge-coupled device (CCD) detector.

elements.content: LnOFs, formulated as [Ln­(H5btp)]·2H2O [Ln3+ = Tb3+ (1) and Gd3+ (2)] were prepared by reacting lanthanide chloride hydrated salts with [1,1′-biphenyl]-3,3′,5,5′-tetrayltetrakis­(phosphonic acid) (H8btp) under hydrothermal conditions. Crystal structure of 1 features two ligand biphenyl groups engaged in π–π interaction in a parallel arrangement, forming an excimer. This allowed the design of an optical ratiometric thermometer using this emission and the 5D4 → 7F5 Tb3+ transition. As the ligand is optically active, the same material may also measure temperature via ligand singlet S 2,1 → S 0 and metal 5D4 → 7F5 transitions. Thus, two alternative ways of measuring temperature become available. From a wider standpoint, this is an attractive concept because external stimuli (adsorption of molecules, pressure, etc.) may impact distinctly these alternative thermometers and we now have a way of assessing whether this is the case.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

LnOFs, formulated as [Ln(H5btp)]⋅2H2O [Ln3+ = Tb3+ (1) and Gd3+ (2)] were prepared by reacting lanthanide chloride hydrated salts with [1,1'-biphenyl]-3,3',5,5'-tetrayltetrakis(phosphonic acid) (H8btp) under hydrothermal conditions. Crystal structure of 1 features two ligand biphenyl groups engaged in π-π interaction in a parallel arrangement, forming an excimer. This allowed the design of an optical ratiometric thermometer using this emission and the 5D4 → 7F5 Tb3+ transition. As the ligand is optically active, the same material may also measure temperature via ligand singlet S 2,1 → S 0 and metal 5D4 → 7F5 transitions. Thus, two alternative ways of measuring temperature become available. From a wider standpoint, this is an attractive concept because external stimuli (adsorption of molecules, pressure, etc.) may impact distinctly these alternative thermometers and we now have a way of assessing whether this is the case.

cln_elements.content: Reactive mixtures composed of the respective lanthanide­(III) chloride hydrates [LnCl3·6H2O, where Ln3+ = Tb3+ (1) and Gd3+ (2)] and 0.025 g of [1,1′-biphenyl]-3,3′,5,5′-tetrayltetrakis­(phosphonic acid) (H8btp), with an overall molar ratio of approximately 1:4 (H8btp:Ln3+), were prepared in a mixture of distilled water, HCl (6 M), and methanol (2 mL each) at ambient temperature. Mixtures were kept under constant magnetic stirring in open air for approximately 15 min. The resulting homogeneous suspensions were transferred to Teflon-lined Parr Instrument reaction vessels and placed inside an MMM Venticell oven. The heating program included (i) heating for 48 h up to 140 °C, (ii) 24 h maintenance of the temperature (140 °C), and (iii) cooling for 48 h until ambient temperature was reached. The resulting materials were isolated as white microcrystalline powders, recovered by vacuum filtration, washed with abundant amounts of distilled water, and dried at ambient temperature.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Ln(H5btp)]⋅2H2O

Reactive mixtures composed of the respective lanthanide(III) chloride hydrates [LnCl3⋅6H2O, where Ln3+ = Tb3+ (1) and Gd3+ (2)] and 0.025 g of [1,1'-biphenyl]-3,3',5,5'-tetrayltetrakis(phosphonic acid) (H8btp), with an overall molar ratio of approximately 1:4 (H8btp:Ln3+), were prepared in a mixture of distilled water, HCl (6 M), and methanol (2 mL each) at ambient temperature. Mixtures were kept under constant magnetic stirring in open air for approximately 15 min. The resulting homogeneous suspensions were transferred to Teflon-lined Parr Instrument reaction vessels and placed inside an MMM Venticell oven. The heating program included (i) heating for 48 h up to 140 °C, (ii) 24 h maintenance of the temperature (140 °C), and (iii) cooling for 48 h until ambient temperature was reached. The resulting materials were isolated as white microcrystalline powders, recovered by vacuum filtration, washed with abundant amounts of distilled water, and dried at ambient temperature.

cln_elements.content:
Photoluminescent isotypical phosphonate-based metal–organic frameworks, [Ln­(H5btp)]·2H2O [where Ln3+ = Tb3+ (1) or Gd3+ (2) and H8btp = [1,1′-biphenyl]-3,3′,5,5′-tetrayltetrakis­(phosphonic acid)] prepared under solvo­(hydro)­thermal conditions exhibit a three-dimensional supramolecular structure built up from phosphonate linkers bridging Ln3+ ions. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction of 1 revealed hydrogen bonds along the a-axis between the crystallization water molecules and the phosphonate groups. The network features lozenge-shaped tubular channels with intermolecular interactions between adjacent organic ligand molecules. Crystal packing forces bring together two ligand biphenyl groups in a parallel arrangement, forming an excimer. A ratiometric luminescent thermometer operative close to room temperature was built based on the excimer and the 5D4 → 7F5 Tb3+ emissions, exhibiting a maximum relative thermal sensitivity of 1.26%·K–1 and a minimum temperature uncertainty of 0.75 K at 319 K. This performance is similar to that of a thermometer based on the ligand singlet S 2,1 → S 0 and metal 5D4 → 7F5 transitions. Thus, the same MOF material provides two separate temperature data sets. This work shows the possibility of using excimer emissions in ratiometric luminescence thermometry.

The last difference Fourier map synthesis showed the highest peak (1.500 e·Å–3) and the deepest hole (−0.749 e·Å–3), located at 1.01 and 0.80 Å from Tb1. Structural refinements were performed with the graphical interface ShelXle. Structural drawings have been created by use of the software package Crystal Impact Diamond. Information concerning crystallographic data collection and structure refinement details is summarized in Table S5. Tables S1 and S2 gather the most significant geometrical parameters of the crystallographically independent Tb3+ coordination sphere and possible supramolecular contacts.

Photoluminescence and Time-Dependent Density Functional Theory Calculations

The UV–vis absorption spectra of H8btp in ethanol solutions (1.0 × 10–4 and 6.2 × 10–4 mol·L–1) exhibit a broad band at 255 nm with high molar absorption coefficients, characteristic of singlet intraligand (1IL) π → π* transitions, and a residual component peaking at ca. 325 nm for the concentrated solution (Figure S3). To rationalize the UV–vis absorption results, the theoretical singlet electronic transitions, oscillator strengths, and molecular orbitals involved in the selected transitions (containing the ethanol solvent effects) were assessed by TD-DFT calculations, for a ground-state H8btp singlet S 0 monomeric structure (Figure S4a). Very good agreement is observed between the calculated lowest singlet, with the largest oscillator strength at 254 nm, and the experimental lowest-energy absorption maximum at 255 nm. A monomeric model cannot explain the small band at 325 nm given by the concentrated solution. This band is ascribed to the equilibrium between monomeric and dimeric structures; that is, to an excimer. To validate this hypothesis, the excitation spectra of H8btp ethanol solutions of concentration 4.0 × 10–5, 2.0 × 10–4, and 1.0 × 10–3 mol·L–1, monitoring the emission at 405 nm, were recorded (Figure S5). As the H8btp concentration decreases, the intensity of the 310–390 nm bands also decreases, in contrast with the increasing intensity of the 260–290 nm bands, confirming the above hypothesis.

Emission spectra of 2 also witness the S 2,1 → S 0 ligand transitions and excimer emission (b). At 12 K, the spectrum excited at 300 nm is dominated by a broad band from ca. 440 to 580 nm, attributed to the ligand’s phosphorescence, with a T 1 triplet-state energy of 22 676 cm–1 (441 nm). However, this phosphorescence disappears upon excitation of the excimer at 370 nm (b). As shown in Figure S6, all the main luminescence characteristics of 2, namely, the fluorescence emission from both S 2,1 and excimer, are observed in the isolated H8btp ligand and, therefore, are intrinsic to it. The low intensity of excimer emission relatively to S 2,1 → S 0 emission (284 nm excitation) is expected, because in the MOF structure π–π interactions between the aromatic rings of the ligands () favor excimer formation. The small shift to higher energy of the emission bands of H8btp in ethanolic solution relative to 2, and the distinct vibronic structure observed for the phosphorescence emission (Figure S6), may be due to the different protonation level and coordination modes of H5btp3–.

The ambient temperature time-resolved emission spectra of 1 (Figure S8) and the decay curves (Figure S9) further confirm the assignment of S 2,1 → S 0 transition and excimer emission. Indeed, these emissions display similar time dependence, much faster than the intra-4f Tb3+ lines. Moreover, the measured lifetimes (emission at 425 nm) are τ1 = 2.33 ± 0.10 ns, α1 = 94.4%, τ2 = 4.67 ± 0.11 ns, α2 = 5.6%, and χ2 = 2.2 for 1 and τ1 = 2.98 ± 0.05 ns, α1 = 91.0%, τ2 = 5.59 ± 0.14 ns, α2 = 9.0%, and χ2 = 2.4 for 2. The detection of two lifetimes is ascribed to the two distinct H5btp3– coordinating groups revealed by crystallography. Our excitation source does not allow excitation of the S 2,1 emission, and thus the decay curves were not measured. The 5D4 decay curves of 1 were recorded at 295 and 12 K. The data are well-described by single-exponential decay functions (Figure S10), yielding lifetimes of 1.23 ± 0.01 ms at 295 K and 2.92 ± 0.01 ms at 13 K, in agreement with the presence of a single Tb3+ crystallographic site. The increase of emission lifetime with decreasing temperature is the result of nonradiative deactivation pathways, also responsible for the increase in ligand-to-Tb3+ energy transfer.

Next, the lowest-excited triplet state of the H8btp monomer was studied by geometry optimization by the unrestricted method (Figure S4d). The ΔSCF approach was applied and, upon geometry relaxation in the T 1 state, an excitation energy of 420 nm was calculates, in good agreement with the 436 nm experimental value of the 0–0 onset energy of the triplet phosphorescence emission at 12 K (Figure S6).

Luminescence Temperature Dependence

To the best of our knowledge, an excimer emission has not yet been used for implementing ratiometric luminescence thermometry. Thus, the excimer emission (together with Tb3+ emission) observed in the present system offers a unique opportunity to assess this possibility and to compare it with the more “conventional” optical thermometry based on ligand fluorescence. For this purpose, the ratios of the integrated areas of the 5D4 → 7F5 (I Tb, 534–560 nm) and of the (i) excimer emission (I E , 390–476 nm) and (ii) ligand S 2,1 → S 0 emission (I S, 316–386 nm) were used to define the thermometric parameters (ΔE = I Tb/I E and ΔS = I Tb/I S), allowing the conversion of emission intensities into absolute temperatures. The emission spectra of 1 at 299–319 K are presented in a. Four consecutive emission spectra were recorded at each temperature and used to determine the average thermometric parameters, with the errors calculated from the corresponding standard deviations (95% confidence). From 299 to 319 K, I Tb, I E, and I S decrease 34%, 18%, and 13%, respectively, (b).

a depicts the temperature dependence of ΔE and ΔS in the 299–319 K range: solid lines depict the calibration curves obtained by fitting the experimental data with linear equations [Δ­(T) = Δ0 + mT], with Δ0 = 34.94 ± 0.71 and m = 0.0922 ± 0.0023 (r 2 = 0.99) for ΔS and Δ0 = 20.18 ± 0.70 and m = 0.0507 ± 0.0023 (r 2 = 0.98) for ΔE. The corresponding relative sensitivity, defined as S r = |∂Δ/∂T|/Δ, a figure of merit used to compare the performance of thermometers independently of their nature, is shown in b. These ratiometric thermometers exhibit good relative sensitivities in the physiological range, with similar maximal relative sensitivities (S m) of 1.66 and 1.26%·K–1 at 319 K, respectively, for ΔS and ΔE. Thus, even if the singlet-based thermometer outperforms the excimer-based thermometer, the latter is a possible alternative. Concerning S m, the singlet-based thermometer is the third highest reported to date for MOF-based visible luminescent ratiometric thermometers operating in the physiological range. S m of 4.47%·K–1 at 333 K was reported for Tb0.995Eu0.005@In­(OH)­(bpydc), where bpydc = 2,2′-bipyridine-5,5′-dicarboxylic acid, and 2.19%·K–1 at 293 K for Eu@UiO­(bpydc). In addition, at the reference human body temperature (309 K), S r for our ΔS (1.43%·K–1) is similar to the best S r values (1.57 and 1.63%·K–1) reported for prior visible luminescent ratiometric Ln-based MOFs ().
